review.title: Log-based Evaluation of Label Splits for Process Models
review.abstract: Process mining techniques aim to extract insights in processes from event logs. One of the challenges in process mining is identifying interesting and meaningful event labels that contribute to a better understanding of the process. Our application area is mining data from smart homes for elderly, where the ultimate goal is to signal deviations from usual behavior and provide timely recommendations in order to extend the period of independent living. Extracting individual process models showing user behavior is an important instrument in achieving this goal. However, the interpretation of sensor data at an appropriate abstraction level is not straightforward. For example, a motion sensor in a bedroom can be triggered by tossing and turning in bed or by getting up. We try to derive the actual activity depending on the context (time, previous events, etc.). In this paper we introduce the notion of label refinements, which links more abstract event descriptions with their more refined counterparts. We present a statistical evaluation method to determine the usefulness of a label refinement for a given event log from a process perspective. Based on data from smart homes, we show how our statistical evaluation method for label refinements can be used in practice. Our method was able to select two label refinements out of a set of candidate label refinements that both had a positive effect on model precision.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The process mining task is the automatic or semi-automatic analysis of events that are logged during the execution of processes, with event records containing information about what was done, by whom, for whom, when, etc. However, events are grouped into cases (process instances), e.g. per patient for a hospital log or per insurance claim for an insurance company. An important task within the process mining is process discovery, which focuses on extracting interpretable models for which the corresponding author is responsible. sections.heading: 4. Evaluation Method for Label Refinements for Process Models
sections.text: In the previous section, we showed that we can compare the usefulness of a label refinement by examining the petri net we obtained with the process refinement. However, a naive method for evaluating label refinement would be to apply the process refinement to all possible label refinements. However, the number of label refinements under consideration can be large and the process finding is a mathematically costly task. Therefore, this naive approach quickly becomes mathematically unfeasible. We now present a way to estimate the usefulness of a label refinement based on statistics and protocol relations. Algorithm 1 shows the steps of the label refinement evaluation method. The evaluation method consists of an entropy component that measures whether a label refinement makes the protocol statistics more unbalanced, and a statistical test that verifies whether there is a label refinement that makes a statistically significant difference to at least one statistical measure of the two.

sections.text: The binary entropy function, Hb (p) = − p log2 p − (1 − p) log2 (1 − p), where 0 log2 0 = 0, is a measure of uncertainty. However, the binary entropy function represents a degree of non-determinism. Non-deterministic, unbalanced, logged statistics are helpful for the process discovery algorithms, which are based on protocol statistics, as they provide a low level of uncertainty about the mining algorithm. sections.heading: 4.4. Correcting for Multiple Testing
sections.text: The computational complexity indicates the number of hypotheses performed. If a large number of potential label refinements are evaluated, the evaluation method described is susceptible to the repeated test problem. The larger the number of hypotheses tested, the higher the probability that the null hypothesis is incorrectly discarded in at least one of the hypotheses tests. By applying a Bonferroni correction 3.4 to the hypotheses tests performed in the statistical evaluation method of label refinements, the familial error rate remains constant.

sections.text: Let's look at the event log in Table 1 and imagine a scenario in which an elderly carer knows from experience that the alarm clock is always set to 8: 30 a.m. On the basis of this expert knowledge, we are able to define a label refinement in such a way that all bedroom movements after 8: 30 a.m. are considered to be wake-up events, while all other bedroom movements are considered pivotal and turning events. The right column shows the refined labels obtained through this expert function. To evaluate the usefulness of this label refinement from the point of view of the process model, we apply the statistical evaluation method described in Section 4. As a parameter, we set the significance threshold to the frequently used value 01.1. Table 5 shows the result of the statistical tests performed as part of the label refinement evaluation. Four hypotheses tests have been performed, followed by Bonferroni-correction of each statistic is immediately indicated as 0,000.14.

sections.heading: 5. Real life evaluation
sections.text: We apply our label refinement to a series of candidate-label refinements to illustrate the effects of label splits in the context of real life processes. Van Kasteren's dataset consists of 1285 events occurring in the days from midnight to midnight. Candidate refinements consist of two event locations each based on time.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion & Future Work
sections.text: We have developed a theoretical and conceptual idea of when label refinements and abstractions are useful from the point of view of process discovery. On the basis of this notion of utility, we have demonstrated a statistical and information theory-based framework for evaluating the usefulness of a label refinement or abstraction. In addition, we have demonstrated the applicability of this statistical framework in a real-life smart home case, where our method has selected two label refinements from a larger set of candidates that have increased the precision of the resulting process model. Methods for automatically tracing useful label refinements from event attributes have yet to be explored. Such methods can produce a series of label refinements by candidates, according to which the statistical evaluation method described in this paper can be used to select the most promising label refinement from a range of candidate label refinements.
